00017 package WeBWorK::Template;
00018 use base qw(Exporter);
00019 
00020 =head1 NAME
00021 
00022 WeBWorK::Template - apply a template to a ContentGenerator.
00023 
00024 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00025 
00026  use WeBWorK::Template qw/template/;
00027  
00028  my $templateFile = "default.template";
00029  my $cg = WeBWorK::ContentGenerator::SomeSubclass->new($r);
00030  
00031  template($templateFile, $cg);
00032 
00033 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00034 
00035 WeBWorK uses templates to customize the presentation of pages. A template is a
00036 complete HTML document, containing normal HTML code and special escape
00037 sequences.
00038 
00039 =head2 ESCAPE SEQUENCES
00040 
00041 Escape sequences have a format similar to that of server-side includes (SSI).
00042 The format is as follows:
00043 
00044  <!--#NAME ARG1="VALUE1" ARG2="VALUE2" ...-->
00045 
00046 An escape's C<NAME> and arguments (C<ARG1>, C<ARG2>, etc.) are case-sensitive,
00047 the argument values may or may not be depending on the particular escape. Most
00048 escapes have case-sensitive values.
00049 
00050 Escape equences are replaced by dynamically generated content from WeBWorK's
00051 content generation system, WeBWorK::ContentGenerator. When a template escape
00052 C<NAME> is encountered in the document, the template processor checks for a
00053 method of the same name in the current content generator. If found, that method
00054 is invoked as follows:
00055 
00056  @result = $contentGenerator->NAME(\%escapeArguments);
00057 
00058 where %escapeArguments contains the key/value pairs of arguments in the escape
00059 sequence (like C<ARG1="VALUE1" ARG2="VALUE2">). The method may print() output
00060 directly to the client or return a result. If the method returns a non-empty
00061 value, it is sent to the client.
00062 
00063 =head2 CONDITIONAL PROCESSING
00064 
00065 In addition to the normal escape sequences above, the escape sequences C<#if>,
00066 C<#else>, and C<#endif> are reserved and used to conditionally include portions
00067 of the template in the output.
00068 
00069 The C<#if> escape sequence has the following form:
00070 
00071  <!--#if PRED1="VALUE1" PRED2="VALUE2" ...->
00072 
00073 When an C<#if> escape is evaluated, each predicate (C<PRED1>, C<PRED2>, etc.) is
00074 evaluated by calling a method named C<if_PRED> in the current content generator
00075 with the predicate's value as the sole argument. If no such method exists, the
00076 predicate is false. If the method returns a true value, the predicate is true.
00077 
00078 If any predicate is true, the code between the C<#if> escape and a matching
00079 C<#else> or C<#endif> escape is included in the output. C<#if> statements can be
00080 nested.
00081 
00082 For example:
00083 
00084  <!--#if loggedin="1"-->
00085  <!--#if can="loginstatus"-->
00086  <div class="LoginStatus">
00087     <!--#loginstatus-->
00088  </div>
00089  <!--#endif-->
00090  <!--#endif-->
00091  <!--#if can="path"-->
00092  <div class="Path">
00093     <!--#path style="text" image="/webwork2_files/images/right_arrow.png" text=" > "-->
00094  </div>
00095  <!--#endif-->
00096 
00097 Several predicate functions are defined in WeBWorK::ContentGenerator.
00098 
00099 =cut
00100 
00101 use strict;
00102 use warnings;
00103 use WeBWorK::Utils qw(readFile);
00104 
00105 our @EXPORT    = ();
00106 our @EXPORT_OK = qw(
00107     template
00108 );
00109 
00110 =head1 FUNCTIONS
00111 
00112 =over
00113 
00114 =item template($templatePath, $cg)
00115 
00116 Process the template file $templatePath. Methods from $cg, an instance of
00117 WeBWorK::ContentGenerator, are called to handle escape sequences in the
00118 template.
00119 
00120 =cut
00121 
00122 sub template {
00123     my ($templatePath, $cg) = @_;
00124     
00125     # the truth value of the top of this stack determines if we're printing output or not.
00126     # we want to start off in printing mode.
00127     # say $ifstack[-1] to get the result of the last <#!--if-->
00128     my @ifstack = (1);
00129     
00130     my @template = split /\n/, readFile($templatePath);
00131     
00132     foreach my $line (@template) {
00133         # This is incremental regex processing.
00134         # the /c is so that pos($line) doesn't die when the regex fails.
00135         while ($line =~ m/\G(.*?)<!--#(\w*)((?:\s+.*?)?)-->/gc) {
00136             my ($before, $function, $raw_args) = ($1, $2, $3);
00137             my @args = ($raw_args =~ /\S/) ? cook_args($raw_args) : ();
00138             
00139             if ($ifstack[-1]) {
00140                 print $before;
00141             }
00142             
00143             if ($function eq "if") {
00144                 # a predicate can only be true if everything else on the ifstack is already true, for ANDing
00145                 push @ifstack, (if_handler($cg, [@args]) && $ifstack[-1]);
00146             } elsif ($function eq "else" and @ifstack > 1) {
00147                 $ifstack[-1] = not $ifstack[-1];
00148             } elsif ($function eq "endif" and @ifstack > 1) {
00149                 pop @ifstack;
00150             } elsif ($ifstack[-1]) {
00151                 if ($cg->can($function)) {
00152                     my @result = $cg->$function({@args});
00153                     if (@result) {
00154                         print @result;
00155                     } else {
00156                         warn "Template escape $function returned an empty list.";
00157                     }
00158                 }
00159             }
00160         }
00161         
00162         if ($ifstack[-1]) {
00163             print substr($line, (defined pos $line) ? pos $line : 0), "\n";
00164         }
00165     }
00166 }
00167 
00168 # cook_args(STRING) - parses a string of the form ARG1="FOO" ARG2="BAR". Returns
00169 # a list which pairs into key/values and fits nicely in {}s.
00170 # 
00171 sub cook_args($) { # ... also used by bin/wwdb, so watch out
00172     my ($raw_args) = @_;
00173     my @args = ();
00174     
00175     # Boy I love m//g in scalar context!  Go read the camel book, heathen.
00176     # First, get the whole token with the quotes on both ends...
00177     while ($raw_args =~ m/\G\s*(\w*)="((?:[^"\\]|\\.)*)"/g) {
00178         my ($key, $value) = ($1, $2);
00179         # ... then, rip out all the protecty backspaces
00180         $value =~ s/\\(.)/$1/g;
00181         push @args, $key => $value;
00182     }
00183     
00184     return @args;
00185 }
00186 
00187 # This is different.  It probably shouldn't print anything (except in debugging cases)
00188 # and it should return a boolean, not a string.  &if is called in a nonstandard way
00189 # by &template, with $args as an arrayref instead of a hashref.  this is a hack!  yay!
00190 # 
00191 # OK, this is a pluggin architecture.  it iterates through attributes of the "if" tag,
00192 # and for each predicate $p, it calls &if_$p in an object-oriented way, continuing the
00193 # grand templating theme of an object-oriented pluggable architecture using ->can($).
00194 # 
00195 sub if_handler {
00196     my ($cg, $args) = @_;
00197     # A single if "or"s it's components.  Nesting produces "and".
00198     
00199     my @args = @$args; # Hahahahaha, get it?!
00200     
00201     if (@args % 2 != 0) {
00202         # flip out and kill people, but do not commit seppuku
00203         print '<!--&if recieved an uneven number of arguments.  This shouldn\'t happen, but I\'ll let it slide.-->\n';
00204     }
00205     
00206     while (@args > 1) {
00207         my ($key, $value) = (shift @args, shift @args);
00208         
00209         # a non-existent &if_$key is the same as a false result, but we're ORing, so it's OK
00210         my $sub = "if_$key"; # perl doesn't like it when you try to construct a string right in a method invocation
00211         if ($cg->can("if_$key") and $cg->$sub("$value")) {
00212             return 1;
00213         }
00214     }
00215     
00216     return 0;
00217 }
00218 
00219 =back
00220 
00221 =cut

00223 1;
